creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund; purchase from the collection of Elizabeth and Willard Clark
description: six-panel folding screen; several groups of figures against gold leaf background; casually clad man sits next to a fabric-wrapped bundle on L; a cluster of five figures follows, two standing girls and a young man leaning in an "S"-curve on his katana; seated in front of this group is a woman and a man; in foreground are two seated figures, one woman with her dog and a girl with her back turned; blind musician playing shamisen, with broken string held with lips; on far R a group of three dancing figures, two women and a man
markings:
LLC. 1. [Ho- koe no I Zeshin];
2: [Shi(ba) no in Zeshin]
medium: Six-panel folding screen; ink and color on gold leaf
provenance: Ishimi Zensuke passed on to Ishimi Tōsuke. Ōhara (Owned it from late 1920s until 1940 when they were sold in Osaka at auction). Osaka Bijutsu Kurabu, Feb. 16, 1940 (元禄美人). Weston acquired them at a Christie's auction and then sold them through Christie's to Bill Clark.
text: This pair of screens was inspired by a masterpiece in the collection of Hikone Castle in Shiga prefecture, popularly known as the Hikone Screen and an example of early 18th-century genre painting that depicts the era’s customs and manners. Fashionable youth in a pleasure quarter enjoy pursuits symbolic of the four elegant accomplishments of Chinese scholars: music, Chinese chess (go), calligraphy, and painting. Zeshin is primarily known for his artistic innovations in lacquer, yet he was also a painter and this is his greatest masterwork. He created at least six paintings modeled after the Hikone Screen. This is the earliest and most lavish. (2013.31.47.2)
title: The Four Elegant Pastimes
